domain: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Bases of Behavior

questions.stem: A public health campaign presents detailed statistical evidence about vaccine efficacy, peer-reviewed study results, and mechanism-of-action data to an audience of healthcare professionals. According to the Elaboration Likelihood Model, which outcome is most likely?

options.text: Attitude change will occur primarily through peripheral processing due to the complexity of the data
Durable, resistant attitude change will occur through central route processing because the audience has both high motivation and high ability
The campaign will fail because statistical evidence is less persuasive than emotional appeals regardless of audience
Attitude change will occur through both routes simultaneously, producing moderately durable change

questions.explanation: The ELM (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986) predicts that when an audience has both high motivation (the topic is professionally relevant) and high ability (expertise to evaluate the arguments), they will process through the central route. Central route processing focuses on argument quality and produces durable, resistant attitude change. Healthcare professionals evaluating vaccine data meet both conditions for central route processing.

questions.stem: A therapist working with a resistant adolescent client says, 'You probably aren't ready to make any changes right now, and that's completely fine.' The adolescent then becomes motivated to demonstrate change. This therapeutic technique most directly leverages which social psychological concept?

options.text: Normative social influence
Psychological reactance
Informational social influence
The foot-in-the-door technique

questions.explanation: Psychological reactance (Brehm, 1966) occurs when people perceive their freedom of choice is being threatened, motivating them to restore that freedom by doing the opposite of what is suggested. The therapist's statement is a paradoxical intervention that leverages reactance -- by implying the client cannot change, the client's reactance motivates them to prove otherwise. This is a well-established technique in motivational interviewing and strategic therapy approaches.

questions.stem: In Milgram's original obedience study, approximately what percentage of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock to the confederate learner?
questions.explanation: In Milgram's (1963) baseline obedience study, 65% of participants (26 out of 40) administered the maximum 450-volt shock to the confederate learner, despite hearing screams and protests. This finding was far higher than predicted by psychiatrists and laypeople, demonstrating the powerful influence of legitimate authority on behavior. This percentage is one of the most commonly tested specific statistics on the EPPP.

questions.stem: A car dealership agrees to sell a vehicle at a very low price. After the customer commits to the purchase and begins paperwork, the salesperson reveals additional fees that significantly increase the total cost. The customer still proceeds with the purchase. Which compliance technique does this illustrate?

options.text: Door-in-the-face technique
That's-not-all technique
Foot-in-the-door technique
Lowball technique

questions.explanation: The lowball technique involves getting a person to commit to an attractive deal and then changing the terms to be less favorable after commitment has been secured. It works through the principle of commitment and consistency -- once people have committed to a course of action, they feel internal pressure to follow through even when the original terms change. This differs from foot-in-the-door (small request then large) and door-in-the-face (large request then small).

questions.stem: According to Hovland's communication model, a persuasive message from a low-credibility source initially produces little attitude change. However, weeks later, the message has a stronger persuasive effect than immediately after exposure. This delayed persuasion effect is known as the:

options.text: Recency effect
Priming effect
Sleeper effect
Mere exposure effect

questions.explanation: The sleeper effect refers to a delayed increase in the persuasive impact of a message from a non-credible source. Initially, the message is discounted because of its low-credibility source. Over time, the message content is remembered but the source is forgotten (dissociation), allowing the message to exert its persuasive influence. This is distinct from the recency effect (advantage of later-presented information), priming (activation of related concepts), and the mere exposure effect (liking through repeated exposure).

questions.stem: Select all factors that have been shown to DECREASE obedience in variations of Milgram's obedience paradigm.

options.text: Having the learner (victim) in the same room as the participant
Conducting the experiment in a prestigious university setting
Having another 'teacher' refuse to continue administering shocks
The experimenter giving orders by telephone rather than in person
Having the participant only read word pairs while another person delivered shocks

questions.explanation: Obedience in Milgram's paradigm decreased when: (a) the learner was physically closer or in the same room (proximity increased empathy and made consequences more salient), (c) social support for defiance was present (another 'teacher' modeling refusal), and (d) the authority figure's presence was reduced (telephone orders). A prestigious setting INCREASED obedience, and having only an indirect role (reading word pairs) also INCREASED obedience by diffusing responsibility.

questions.stem: Select all factors that Asch's conformity research demonstrated increase the rate of conformity in the line judgment task.

options.text: Increasing the task difficulty or ambiguity of the stimuli
Having participants give their responses publicly rather than privately
Including even one dissenter who gives a different wrong answer
Increasing group size from 1 to 3-4 confederates
Increasing group size from 7 to 15 confederates

questions.explanation: Conformity in Asch's paradigm increased with: (a) greater task difficulty/ambiguity, (b) public rather than private responding, and (d) group size up to about 3-4 members. Having even one dissenter (c) dramatically REDUCED conformity, even if the dissenter gave a different wrong answer. Increasing group size beyond 3-4 (e) did not substantially increase conformity further -- the effect plateaus.

questions.stem: According to the Elaboration Likelihood Model, select all conditions that promote central route processing of a persuasive message.

options.text: The audience has high personal relevance to the topic
The audience is distracted during message presentation
The audience has sufficient knowledge to evaluate the arguments
The message source is physically attractive
The audience has a high need for cognition

questions.explanation: Central route processing requires both high motivation and high ability to process the message. High personal relevance (a) and high need for cognition (e) increase motivation, while sufficient knowledge (c) provides the ability to evaluate arguments. Distraction (b) reduces processing ability and pushes toward the peripheral route. Source attractiveness (d) is a peripheral cue that matters when central processing is low.

questions.stem: Select all compliance techniques that operate primarily through the principle of reciprocity according to Cialdini's framework.

options.text: Door-in-the-face technique (starting with a large request, then retreating to a smaller one)
Foot-in-the-door technique (starting with a small request, then escalating)
That's-not-all technique (sweetening the deal before the person decides)
Lowball technique (changing the terms after initial agreement)
Free sample marketing strategies

questions.explanation: The reciprocity principle underlies: (a) the door-in-the-face technique, which works through reciprocal concessions -- the requester 'concedes' by reducing the request, creating pressure to reciprocate with compliance; (c) the that's-not-all technique, which creates a sense of receiving an additional favor; and (e) free samples, which create a sense of obligation to reciprocate. The foot-in-the-door (b) and lowball (d) techniques both operate through commitment and consistency, not reciprocity.

questions.stem: According to Hovland's communication research, select all statements that are accurate about fear appeals in persuasive messages.

options.text: Moderate levels of fear are generally most effective for attitude change
Extremely high fear always produces the strongest persuasion due to motivational arousal
Fear appeals are most effective when paired with clear, actionable recommendations
Too much fear can produce defensive avoidance rather than attitude change
Fear appeals are equally effective regardless of audience self-efficacy

questions.explanation: Hovland's research and subsequent work established that: (a) moderate fear is most effective; (c) fear appeals must be accompanied by clear behavioral recommendations to be effective; and (d) excessive fear triggers defensive avoidance or denial rather than attitude change. Extremely high fear (b) backfires by overwhelming the audience. Self-efficacy (e) moderates effectiveness -- people must believe they can perform the recommended action.

questions.stem: Match each compliance technique to the primary Cialdini principle of influence it exploits.
questions.explanation: Foot-in-the-door works through commitment and consistency -- once a person agrees to a small request, they feel pressure to remain consistent by agreeing to larger requests. Door-in-the-face works through reciprocity (reciprocal concessions) -- the requester 'concedes' by lowering the request, creating pressure to reciprocate. Celebrity endorsements exploit the liking principle -- we are more persuaded by people we like or admire. 'Only 3 left' exploits scarcity -- people value things more when they are rare or diminishing.

questions.stem: Match each persuasion concept to the researcher most closely associated with it.
questions.explanation: Petty and Cacioppo (1986) developed the Elaboration Likelihood Model distinguishing central and peripheral routes to persuasion. Cialdini (1984) identified six principles of influence: reciprocity, commitment/consistency, social proof, authority, liking, and scarcity. Milgram (1963) conducted the famous obedience studies where participants administered shocks to a confederate. Asch (1951) demonstrated conformity through his line judgment paradigm, showing 75% of participants conformed at least once.

questions.stem: For each type of social influence, select ALL features that accurately describe it. Multiple selections per row are required.

columns.text: Driven by desire for social approval/acceptance
Relies on superficial cues or heuristics

questions.explanation: Normative influence is driven by the desire for social approval (c2), producing public compliance without private acceptance. Informational influence produces genuine private attitude change (c1) because people believe the group has better information. Central route persuasion produces both genuine attitude change (c1) and durable, resistant attitudes (c3) through deep argument evaluation. Peripheral route persuasion relies on superficial cues (c4) such as source attractiveness or number of arguments, producing temporary attitude change.

questions.stem: For each Milgram study variation described below, select ALL outcomes that were observed. Multiple selections per row are required.

rows.text: Learner in same room as teacher (proximity condition)

columns.text: Participants showed visible signs of distress
Participants sometimes lied about shock levels

questions.explanation: In the baseline condition, 65% obeyed fully (c1) and participants showed significant distress (c3) including sweating, trembling, and nervous laughter. When the learner was in the same room (proximity), obedience decreased substantially (c2) but participants still showed distress (c3). When orders were given by telephone, obedience decreased (c2) and some participants lied about administering shocks (c4), claiming they were following orders while actually delivering lower voltages. When another teacher modeled defiance, obedience dropped dramatically (c2).

questions.stem: In Asch's line studies, approximately {{blank1}} of participants conformed at least once across trials. The overall conformity rate across all trials was about {{blank2}}. Conformity dropped sharply when {{blank3}} was present. Asch's studies primarily demonstrated the power of {{blank4}} influence, where people conform to be accepted by the group.

options.text: an authority figure
a larger group size
even one dissenter
written rather than verbal responses
informational
normative
coercive
referent

questions.explanation: In Asch's conformity studies, 75% of participants conformed at least once, though the overall per-trial conformity rate was about 37%. The presence of even one dissenter -- even one giving a different wrong answer -- sharply reduced conformity. Because the line judgment task had an objectively correct answer, conformity was driven primarily by normative influence (desire for social acceptance) rather than informational influence (believing the group was correct).

questions.stem: The door-in-the-face technique works by first making a {{blank1}} request that is likely to be refused, then retreating to the {{blank2}} request. This technique exploits the principle of {{blank3}} because the requester's concession creates pressure on the target to make a reciprocal concession. In contrast, the foot-in-the-door technique exploits the principle of {{blank4}}.

options.text: small and easy
unreasonably large
moderately difficult
ambiguous and vague
even larger
identical
smaller target
unrelated
social proof
scarcity
reciprocity
authority
commitment and consistency
reciprocity
social proof
liking

questions.explanation: The door-in-the-face technique starts with an unreasonably large request (which will be refused), then retreats to the actual target request. It works through reciprocity (specifically reciprocal concessions) -- when the requester 'gives in' by lowering their request, the target feels obligated to reciprocate by giving in too. The foot-in-the-door technique (small request then large) works through commitment and consistency -- once a person complies with a small request, they view themselves as someone who helps and feel pressure to remain consistent.

questions.stem: A researcher studying a cult observes that new members are given small gifts upon arrival, asked to sign a pledge of loyalty early on, and surrounded by uniformly enthusiastic existing members who all express identical beliefs.

options.text: Reciprocity from receiving gifts creates a sense of obligation
Social proof from unanimous group members validates beliefs
The scarcity principle makes membership seem exclusive
Central route processing of strong arguments produces genuine conversion
Systematic exploitation of Cialdini's principles of social influence
Cognitive dissonance from counter-attitudinal behavior
Classical conditioning of emotional responses to group stimuli
Commitment and consistency pressure makes it increasingly difficult to leave
Members' attitudes are vulnerable to counter-persuasion because they formed through peripheral processing
Members develop deep, durable attitude change resistant to deprogramming
Members show increased critical thinking due to informational influence

questions.explanation: The cult uses multiple Cialdini influence principles simultaneously: reciprocity (gifts create obligation), social proof (unanimous members validate beliefs), and commitment/consistency (signing a pledge). The central concept is systematic exploitation of Cialdini's principles. Key implications include: commitment escalation making it harder to leave, and vulnerability to counter-persuasion because attitude change occurred through peripheral route processing (superficial cues) rather than deep argument evaluation, meaning the attitudes are not deeply internalized.

questions.stem: During a corporate meeting, a junior employee notices that the CEO proposes a flawed marketing strategy. All senior executives immediately express enthusiastic agreement. The junior employee remains silent despite believing the strategy is problematic.

options.text: Presence of a high-status authority figure (CEO) exerts pressure to comply
Unanimous agreement of other group members creates normative pressure
The junior employee lacks the competence to evaluate the strategy
The strategy is genuinely good and the employee's doubts are unfounded
Conformity driven by normative social influence and authority pressure
Informational social influence from the group's superior expertise
Cognitive dissonance reduction through attitude change
The employee experiences public compliance without private acceptance of the strategy
Having even one other dissenting voice would likely embolden the employee to speak up
The employee has permanently changed their private attitude to match the group
Increasing the group size beyond the current number would dramatically increase conformity pressure

questions.explanation: This scenario demonstrates normative conformity in a workplace setting. Contributing factors include the authority of the CEO (Milgram's authority principle) and unanimous agreement creating normative pressure (Asch's findings). The employee conforms publicly but maintains private disagreement -- this is the hallmark of normative influence. Key implications: Asch demonstrated that even one dissenter dramatically reduces conformity, and the fact that the employee privately disagrees confirms this is public compliance without private acceptance. Group size beyond 3-4 adds little additional conformity pressure (Asch).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate according to established social influence research.
questions.passage: Social influence research has established several well-replicated findings. [In Asch's line studies, conformity increased steadily as group size increased from 1 to 15 confederates]. [The Elaboration Likelihood Model predicts that central route processing produces more durable attitude change than peripheral route processing]. [Milgram's obedience rates decreased when the experimenter was physically present giving orders in person]. [Moscovici's research demonstrated that consistent minorities can produce genuine private attitude change in the majority through informational influence]. [The foot-in-the-door technique works through the principle of reciprocity by creating a sense of obligation]. [Psychological reactance theory predicts that threatening a person's perceived freedom can produce behavior opposite to what is demanded].

highlightableSegments.text: In Asch's line studies, conformity increased steadily as group size increased from 1 to 15 confederates
The Elaboration Likelihood Model predicts that central route processing produces more durable attitude change than peripheral route processing
Milgram's obedience rates decreased when the experimenter was physically present giving orders in person
Moscovici's research demonstrated that consistent minorities can produce genuine private attitude change in the majority through informational influence
The foot-in-the-door technique works through the principle of reciprocity by creating a sense of obligation
Psychological reactance theory predicts that threatening a person's perceived freedom can produce behavior opposite to what is demanded

questions.explanation: Correct statements: (h2) Central route processing does produce more durable, resistant attitude change than peripheral. (h4) Moscovici showed consistent minorities influence majorities through informational influence, producing genuine private attitude change. (h6) Reactance theory (Brehm) correctly predicts that threatening freedom motivates oppositional behavior. Incorrect: (h1) Conformity plateaued at 3-4 confederates, not 15. (h3) Obedience INCREASED with experimenter present; it DECREASED when orders were given by telephone. (h5) Foot-in-the-door works through commitment/consistency, not reciprocity.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe components of Hovland's communication model of persuasion.
questions.passage: Hovland's Yale Communication Research Program identified key variables affecting persuasion. [Expert and trustworthy sources are more persuasive, particularly when the audience is processing through the central route]. [Two-sided messages acknowledging opposing views are more effective with educated or initially skeptical audiences]. [The primacy effect in persuasion means that when two opposing messages are presented back-to-back, the first message has greater impact]. [High self-monitors are more responsive to quality-based appeals emphasizing product superiority]. [People high in need for cognition are more easily persuaded by peripheral cues such as source attractiveness]. [Moderate fear appeals paired with clear, actionable recommendations are generally more effective than extreme fear appeals].

highlightableSegments.text: Expert and trustworthy sources are more persuasive, particularly when the audience is processing through the central route
Two-sided messages acknowledging opposing views are more effective with educated or initially skeptical audiences
The primacy effect in persuasion means that when two opposing messages are presented back-to-back, the first message has greater impact
High self-monitors are more responsive to quality-based appeals emphasizing product superiority
People high in need for cognition are more easily persuaded by peripheral cues such as source attractiveness
Moderate fear appeals paired with clear, actionable recommendations are generally more effective than extreme fear appeals

questions.explanation: Correct: (h2) Two-sided messages are indeed more effective with educated/skeptical audiences. (h3) The primacy effect correctly states that back-to-back messages favor the first. (h6) Moderate fear paired with actionable recommendations is most effective. Incorrect: (h1) Source credibility is actually more influential via the peripheral route (source credibility is a peripheral cue); strong arguments matter more for central route. (h4) High self-monitors are responsive to IMAGE-based appeals, not quality-based; LOW self-monitors respond to quality. (h5) High need for cognition people are MORE persuaded by strong arguments (central route), not peripheral cues.

questions.stem: Arrange the following events in the correct chronological order as they would typically occur in a foot-in-the-door compliance sequence, from first to last.

items.text: The requester identifies the target person and establishes initial rapport
A small, easy-to-agree-to request is made (e.g., signing a petition)
The target complies with the small request
The target begins to view themselves as someone who supports the cause (self-perception shift)
The larger target request is presented (e.g., volunteering for 10 hours)
The target complies with the larger request to remain consistent with their self-image

questions.explanation: The foot-in-the-door technique follows a specific psychological sequence: First, rapport is established. Then a small request is made and complied with. This compliance triggers a self-perception shift -- the person begins to see themselves as someone who supports the cause (Bem's self-perception theory). When the larger request is presented later, the person complies to maintain consistency with their new self-concept. This technique works through Cialdini's principle of commitment and consistency.

questions.stem: Arrange the following factors from MOST to LEAST effective at reducing obedience in Milgram's paradigm, based on the degree of obedience reduction observed.

items.text: Having another 'teacher' model defiance by refusing to continue
Requiring the participant to physically place the learner's hand on the shock plate (touch proximity)
Having the experimenter deliver orders by telephone rather than in person
Placing the learner in the same room as the participant (proximity condition)
Conducting the study in a less prestigious office building instead of Yale University
Having the learner mention a pre-existing heart condition at the start

questions.explanation: Based on Milgram's experimental variations, social support for defiance (another teacher refusing) produced the greatest reduction in obedience (dropping to about 10%). Touch proximity (physically forcing the learner's hand onto the shock plate) was the next most effective, followed by telephone orders from the experimenter (many participants cheated by giving lower shocks). Having the learner in the same room (proximity) moderately reduced obedience. Moving to a less prestigious setting produced a modest reduction. The heart condition mention had the least effect on actual obedience rates, though it increased participants' distress.

questions.stem: A researcher measures the persuasive impact of a message delivered by a low-credibility source at five time points after exposure. The graph shows the persuasive impact score over time.
questions.question: Which concept best explains the pattern shown for the low-credibility source?

options.text: The mere exposure effect, where repeated contact with the message increases its persuasive impact
The sleeper effect, where the message gains persuasive impact over time as it becomes dissociated from the discredited source
The primacy effect, where early exposure creates a lasting impression that strengthens over time
Central route processing, where deep engagement with argument quality produces increasing attitude change

questions.explanation: The data show the classic sleeper effect pattern: the low-credibility source initially has low persuasive impact, but this impact increases over time as the message content becomes dissociated from its discredited source. Meanwhile, the high-credibility source's impact decreases over time. The two converge at approximately 4-6 weeks. This demonstrates that over time, people remember the message content but forget who delivered it, allowing the message to exert its persuasive influence independent of source credibility.

questions.stem: A researcher measures conformity rates across different experimental conditions in a modified Asch paradigm, varying the number of confederates who give the wrong answer.
questions.question: What does this data pattern demonstrate about the relationship between group size and conformity?

options.text: Conformity increases linearly with group size, showing that larger groups always produce more conformity
Conformity increases with group size up to about 3-4 members and then plateaus, with additional members adding little effect
Conformity peaks at 3 confederates and then decreases as participants become suspicious of larger unanimous groups
Conformity is unrelated to group size and remains constant across all conditions

questions.explanation: Asch's research demonstrated that conformity increases with group size but only up to about 3-4 members, after which additional group members add little to no additional conformity pressure. The data show a sharp increase from 0 to 3 confederates (1% to 33%), followed by near-complete plateauing at 7 (35%) and 15 (36%) confederates. Self-reported confidence follows an inverse pattern, declining rapidly then leveling off. This plateau effect is one of the most well-established findings from Asch's conformity research.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario into the type of social influence it primarily demonstrates.

items.text: A teenager publicly agrees with friends' music preferences despite privately disliking the music, to avoid social exclusion
A new employee in an unfamiliar city asks colleagues which neighborhoods are safe and follows their advice
A nurse administers an unusually high medication dose because a physician ordered it, despite personal reservations
A student laughs at a joke they do not find funny because everyone else in the group is laughing
A person unfamiliar with wine chooses the same bottle as an experienced sommelier at the table
A soldier carries out a morally questionable order from a commanding officer during wartime

questions.explanation: Normative influence (conforming to be liked/accepted): The teenager and the student both publicly conform while privately disagreeing -- the hallmark of normative influence driven by fear of social rejection. Informational influence (conforming to be correct): The new employee and the wine novice both genuinely adopt others' judgments because they believe those others have better information -- this produces true private acceptance. Obedience to authority: The nurse and the soldier both comply with orders from legitimate authority figures, demonstrating the Milgram-type dynamic where status and role relationships drive compliance.

questions.stem: Categorize each persuasion scenario according to whether it primarily involves central route or peripheral route processing, or represents a resistance to persuasion phenomenon.

items.text: A physician carefully evaluates clinical trial data before prescribing a new medication
A consumer buys a product because their favorite athlete endorses it on television
A teenager rebels against parental restrictions on dating by secretly dating more
A voter reads both candidates' detailed policy platforms before deciding
A jury member is swayed by the attorney's confident delivery rather than the evidence presented
A client becomes more committed to smoking after a heavy-handed anti-smoking intervention

questions.explanation: Central route processing involves deep evaluation of argument quality: the physician evaluating clinical data and the voter reading policy platforms both carefully assess the merits of the arguments. Peripheral route processing relies on superficial cues: the consumer responding to celebrity endorsement and the juror swayed by delivery style are both using heuristic shortcuts rather than evaluating argument quality. Resistance to persuasion: the rebellious teenager and the client who increases smoking both demonstrate psychological reactance -- perceiving their freedom as threatened, they act in opposition to the persuasion attempt.
